channel.title: Home on EnzymeML Project
channel.description: Recent content in Home on EnzymeML Project

item.title: EnzymeML 1.0 released
item.description: The specifications for Release 1.0 of EnzymeML are now under preprapration and will be abailable from the Downloads page. Preprint submitted The EnzymeML team submitted the first version of EnzymeML for publication. The reference for the preprint is: Range J, Halupczok C, Lohmann J, Swainston N, Kettner C, Bergmann FT, Weidemann A, Wittig U, Schnell S, Pleiss J (2020). EnzymeML – a data exchange format for biocatalysis and enzymology. Preprint Please state tune for future updates about our first release.

item.title: Juergen Pleiss
item.description: Bioinformatics Group Leader, Institute of Biochemistry and Technical Biochemistry, University of Stuttgart, Germany.

item.title: JEnzyme
item.description: JEnzyme is a free, open-source, pure-Java library for working with EnzymeML. It helps to read and write EnzymeML documents. STRENDA Guidelines The STRENDA Guidelines are available on….

item.title: Specifications
item.description: The EnzymeML specifications define the syntax and semantics of EnzymeML. These documents are the definitive references for EnzymeML. They will be made available upon submission of our first paper. Please state tune for future updates. STRENDA Guidelines EnzymeML helps you to implement the STRENDA Guidelines. These guidelines aim to support authors to comprehensively report kinetic and equilibrium data from their investigations of enzyme activities.

item.title: Neil Swainston
item.description: Senior Research Associate, Institute of Integrative Biology in the University of Liverpool, UK.

item.title: For experimentalists
item.description: How can EnzymeML help you to manage your experimental data? Managing experimental data with EnzymeML Measured time course data on substrate and/or product concentrations is saved in the same document with metadata about the enzyme and the reaction conditions. This faciliates replicability and reproducibility of experimental assays. EnzymeML documents are standardized, so their format is independent of the experimental scientist. Documents are machine- and human-readable. Markup languanges (ML) are specifically designed for machines, and therefore they are not optimally for user reading.

item.title: PyEnzyme
item.description: JEnzyme is a free, open-source, Python library for working with EnzymeML. It helps to read and write EnzymeML documents. Original Peer Review Papers Paper 1 Paper 2

item.title: Use cases
item.description: In this page, you will find find details of selected case studies applying EnzymeML for experimentalists, modelers and software developers. Original Peer Review Papers The first case studies are decribed in our preprint below. Range J, Halupczok C, Lohmann J, Swainston N, Kettner C, Bergmann FT, Weidemann A, Wittig U, Schnell S, Pleiss J (2020). EnzymeML – a data exchange format for biocatalysis and enzymology. Preprint

item.title: Publications
item.description: This section lists published papers and chapters describing EnzymeML and core EnzymeML-supporting software tools. Original Peer Review Papers Malzacher S, Range J, Halupczok C, Pleiss J, Rother D (2020). BioCatHub, a graphical user interface for standardized data acquisition in biocatalysis. Chemie Ingenieur Technik 92, 1251-1251. https://doi.org/10.1002/cite.202055297 Range J, Halupczok C, Lohmann J, Swainston N, Kettner C, Bergmann FT, Weidemann A, Wittig U, Schnell S, Pleiss J (2020).

item.title: Frank T. Bergmann
item.description: Modeling of Biological Processes Group in Centre for Organismal Studies, Heidelberg University, Germany.

item.title: For modelers
item.description: How can EnzymeML help you developing, implementing and analysing models? Here we present you one example to illustrate the power of EnzymeML for modelers. Kinetic modeling of EnzymeML data with COPASI Experimental data on enzyme kinetics (reaction conditions, enzyme concentration, time course of substrate and product concentrations) is stored in a single EnzymeML document and can uploaded to the biochemical system simulator COPASI. Within COPASI, different reaction mechanisms can be tested by selecting different kinetic laws and estimating kinetic parameters.

item.title: Specific APIs
item.description: A free, open-source API library for working with EnzymeML content. It presently supports COPASI, SABIO-RK and STRENDA DB. Original Peer Review Papers Paper 1 Paper 2 This is a test

item.title: Santiago Schnell
item.description: Interim Chair, Department of Molecular & Integrative Physiology, University of Michigan Medical School, USA.

item.title: For software developers
item.description: Want to implement EnzymeML read and write functionalities in your software or database? Here we present you an example to inspire your team. EnzymeML is compatible with SMBL EnzymeML is an extension of SBML. All additional information that are specific to enzyme-catalyzed are added as annotation in a standard SBML file. Thus, EnzymeML is compatible with SBML. You can easily implement an EnzymeML read and write functionality for software applications, such as electronic lab notebooks, laboratory information management systems, modelling platforms, or databases.

item.title: Software and Databases Guide
item.description: The EnzymeML Software and Database Guide provides a summary of all EnzymeML-compatible software systems and databases currently available. COPASI COPASI is a software application for simulation and analysis of biochemical networks and their dynamics. COPASI is a stand-alone program that supports models in the SBML standard and can simulate their behavior using ODEs or Gillespie’s stochastic simulation algorithm; arbitrary discrete events can be included in such simulations. COPASI is a versatile with powerful features for representing enzyme models, simulation, and data analysis, visulaization and output.

item.title: Validators
item.description: A portable, low-level, tools for annocating and validating EnzymeML files.

item.title: Contact
item.description: EnzymeML Project Contacts For questions, suggestions, or participation in the EnzymeML project, please contact the project coordinators: Jürgen Pleiss, Neil Swainston, or Santiago Schnell. STRENDA Guidelines If you are interested to learn more about the STRENDA Guidelines, please contact Carsten Kettner. Website Santiago Schnell is the primary contact for the website updates. This website was developed by modying the Hugo Serif theme by zerostatic.
